Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Sammy wanted to go to where the people were.  Where might he go? Choices:  A: race track B: populated areas C: the desert D: apartment E: roadblock<n><n>### Response:		<n>    - E<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What home entertainment equipment requires cable? Choices:  A: radio shack B: substation C: cabinet D: television E: desk<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>The answer is: E<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>* Answer:E<n>* Demonstration:The key concept for this problem is to look at the choices that have cable in the product name as well as the equipment that can't survive without cable.<n>* Explanation:Cable is essential equipment for these things: 1)home entertainment, 2)radio shack, 3)electrical and 4)desktop. So only cabinet is not using cable.<n>* Explanation 2 : Radio shack, television, cabinet and desk all uses cable. If the answer is not B : 13 then it must be E:desk.<n>

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:James was cooling off two quickly.  He would die if he didn't find some way to stop what? Choices:  A: loss of heat B: revenge C: expansion D: relaxation E: calm down<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choice A<n><n>We say, "The heat death of the universe is when the universe is sufficiently old and dispersed that it has cooled below the minimum temperature needed to sustain nuclear fusion or other reactions that create a source of significant energy."<n><n>### Input Choice 2:<n>Four girls were waiting for their bus to come. Their average age was more than 42 years. They were having some snacks. The ages of their snacks were greater than 2 times the sum 33. What were the ages of the girls?<n><n>Four girls were sitting outside a cafe. Their average age was 42 years. Their snacks’ ages was 33, 46, 62 and 77 years respectively.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What type of person typically contracts illness? Choices:  A: hospital B: head C: sick person D: elderly person E: doctor's office<n><n>### Response:		This is correct. In the given statement, which type of person typically contract a disease? Elderly people and doctors who are sick frequently do not take care of themselves. If you take care of yourself, you are much less likely to get sick.<n><n>### Input What type of person is sick? Choices: A: hospital B: doctors C: head D: patient E: doctor's clinic<n>### Response:The correct answer is B. The patient in the hospital will not be sick. There are many reasons why a patient in a hospital is likely to feel sick, such as due to poor conditions. A doctors office is often visited by sick people, but they are not considered sick.<n><n>## Solution<n>## Problem 1<n><n>## Solution <n>Learning Goals: Students will be able to write a program that gives the product of all divisors of the given number within three trials of guessing. The three guesses must use the prime factorization method (the Sieve of Eratosthenes algorithm). The order of the output will be the divisors of A*B.<n><n># **Part 1: Testing:**<n>```<n>> python prime_factors.py<n>    Please enter a number: 5<n>    Please enter a positive prime number: 2<n>```<n>```<n>> python -m time prime_factors.main -s 5<n>    Please press <ENTER> to begin:<n>    5<n>    Please enter the prime number you know: 2<n>    Please enter the positive prime number you know (for example, 5 is 5, not 2): 2<n>```<n>Part 2: Submission:<n>```<n>> python main_prime_factors.py -s 5<n>    <n>```<n>##### Input 1: 15<n>##### First output divisor: 1<n>##### Second Output divisor: 3<n>##### Third output divisor: 4<n>##### Final output from program: 1,3,4<n># **Part 3: Discussion:**<n>Input 1: 10<n>The first possible option should be to input:<n>```<n>> time python main.main -s 10<n>```<n>Output:<n>```<n>    Please enter a prime number: 3<n>    Please enter the divisor: 2<n>    ><n>```

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Which entrance would you use if you do not want to use the back entrance? Choices:  A: side B: main C: anterior D: current E: front<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Input and instruction:The following numbers are all divisible by 3. The first and the last numbers are divisible by 3 without a remainder. The fourth number is divisible by 3 with a remainder of 6. Input: 9, 21, 15, 24, 27 Determine the value of x. The fifth number is divisible by both 3 and 5 without a remainder and the sixth number is divisible by neither 5 nor 11.<n><n>### Response<n>4<n><n>### Input<n>In order to find what year a person graduated, you only need to know the school's graduation date and how many graduations were from that school in that year. For example, the school had 8 graduates in 2005.  This year the school had 84 graduates and the total students in the school was 321.<n>What year did this person graduate?<n><n>### Answer<n>2005<n><n>### Input 1<n>Given a string representing month in two digit format and a string representing date in four digit format. Calculate first day of the next month.<n><n>### Input/1<n>Jan 11<n>12th Jan<n><n>### Solution 1<n>`str1[1] - 1` + `str1[1]+str1[9]`+`str1[2]-1`<n><n>### Input2:<n>1 Nov<n>11 Nov<n>12 Nov<n>13 Nov<n><n>### Solution2: <n><n>### Instructions:<n>```<n>Given a number N, a 3 digit positive integer P and a 4 digit positive integer Q, you need to reverse the string in such a way that N is the sum of P+Q. Return a 1 letter positive integer, 1 if the task succeeds and 0 if not.<n>Ex. input:<n>1 2 3<n>10 20 30<n>10<n>1<n>answer 0<n><n>```<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What kind of place could have a seafood restaurant? Choices:  A: new york B: coastal cities C: city D: coastal cities E: boston<n><n>### Response:		<n>### The place can be in the cities and coastal areas and it can be in New York and Boston or New England.<n>### The seafood means fish and other things from the sea and a restaurant is the place  to eat a seafood.<n>### Cities are located on land near to the sea.<n>### Coastal cities are located by the sea and they are: New York, Boston, and New England.<n>## <n><n>---<n><n>```ruby<n>class Array<n><n>  def method_missing(name, *args)<n>    if name.to_s == '$'<n>      $$<n>    else<n>      array<n>    end<n>  end<n><n>  def methods(modifiers={})<n>    inject([]) do |h, m|<n>      case m<n>        when :public<n>          m.send(1)<n>        when :private, :protected<n>          m.send(:to_sym)<n>        else<n>          m.to_s.intern if Modules::RUBY_1_9  && m.to_s =~ /^(?:private|protected)$/<n>          m.send:(modifiers[:instance_variables]? :instance_variable_get : :instance_method)<n>      end<n>    end<n>  rescue NameError<n>    []<n>  end<n><n>end<n>```<n><n>```ruby<n><n><b>array</b> = [1,2,3]<n>array.push("a","b","c")<n>array.pop  # 3<n>array.unshift('x','y','z')  # 1<n>array.shift # x<n>array[4] # y<n>array.last # z<n>array == [1,2,1,2,3,a,b,c,x,y,z].sort<n>array.pop while array.size < 5<n>array.map! { |x| 6 - x }.compact<n><n>array.map! do |x| 6-x end<n>array.map!('e')<n><n>array.each_with_index { |x, i| puts "#{i} - #{x}" }<n>array.size # 11<n><n>array.reject do |x| 10.0==x and 9 < x<n>array.count {}<n>```<n><n>[Blog Post](/

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What group of musicians will include someone playing the cello? Choices:  A: ocean B: symphony C: band D: music store E: music shop<n><n>### Response:		<n>Select the one best choice<n><n>### Explanation:<n>The cello in B, D, and E.<n><n>### Input1:What is the number of books? Choices: 150 200 375 425<n>375 because the group has 75 more books than the group before.<n><n>### Response<n><n>Select the one best Choice<n><n>### Input2:What is the number? Choices: 900 2000 3500 A: is the total amount B: of cards C: of money D: of calories E: of calories<n><n>### Reponse<n>Select the one best answer<n><n>### Input3:Select the option that correctly describes the shampoo’s price. Choices:  A. $11  B $19 C. $25 D. $49<n><n>### Reosnse<n>Select the one best response<n><n>### Output<n>$49<n><n>## Coding<n>For your convenience, you are provided a method named `count_cards` that can be used to count the cards in a deck.<n><n>import re<n><n>def question_one():<n>    num_cards = 50<n>    deck = [2, 3, 4, 5, 6]<n>    result = count_cards(deck)<n>    print()<n>    print("How many cards do they have??", result)<n>    print()

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:A person lived in my what? Choices:  A: demonstration B: conference C: building D: garage E: mouth<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choices: A, B<n><n>### Input<n>Mara has 40 cards more than 150. Janet has 9 less than Brenda.<n><n>### Response<n>Mara's cards are 9 less than Brendas, Janet has 9 more than Brenda, So Janet has 18 less than brenda, but 40 more than Mara.<n>So Janet has 21 more cards than Mara<n><n>### Output<n>Janet has 38 cards less than brenda. But Brenda has 49 more than brenda. so Janet still has 21 cards. <n><n>### Input#1<n>4.5 gallons:<n><n>I:	1 gallon is 1 pint<n>	5 gallons is 2 pints<n><n>II:	I have 1.5 pints.<n>	1:5=2<n>	2 pints=3.5 pints<n>		5pints-3.5pints=1.5pints<n><n>### Input #2<n>There are 10 blue:<n><n>10/3=3<n>	3pints:<n>		3 blue:<n>			-1:3=0 (zero)<n>	 3 pints	<n><n>II:	Pretend the pints are gallons:<n>	1/1= 1<n>	<n>	3 green chairs:<n>		1 green chair 				- 3 green chair <n>		1 green chairs + 2 green chair

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. Choices:  A: idaho B: shopping mall C: big city D: in town E: new york<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Why?:<n>Answer A is correct. More people are likely to go to a new store on the outskirts of town than to go to a new department store in a tiny town. When someone goes into a mall, they usually go for other reasons, and going to a specific business (a department store) is not likely.<n><n>### Next:<n><n>A.  10<n><n>B.  5<n><n>C.  25<n><n>D.  1<n><n>### Input<n>You are looking for a pet, but not just any pet! As with all of the tasks there is no correct answer, but a response that appropriately answers the request.<n><n>To show the best possible response, be sure to include the following:<n><n>1. Clear instructions - Include complete step by step instructions that provide enough context for someone to reproduce the response;<n><n>2. Corresponding images and screenshots  - If using images and screenshots be sure to include them to show the work of your response;<n><n>4. The next number will be 65.<n>

The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What would you put furniture on top of? Choices:  A: roof B: room C: floor D: apartment E: neighbor's house<n><n>### Response:		<n>I would put furniture on top on the roof as it makes it less likely to fall off.<n><n>### Input<n>What would you like to have 100 more of? Choices: A: sand B: candy C: shoes D: toys E: books<n><n>### Response Answer<n><n>### Input Choices:<n>Choices: A: 25 B: 30 C: 29 D: 21 E: 75<n>What would you use a calendar for?<n>### Response<n><n>### Input <n>What are people going to use the calendar for?<n>The answer options for every question are:<n>- 25<n>- 30<n>- 29<n>- 21<n>- 75<n>### Response<n>Some people will like to use the calendar to keep track of important events in their life and keep on track about what to do in each day.<n><n>### 2nd input<n>What should you do when you're bored?<n><n>### Response<n>I've seen it as a good time to get a lot of work done. However, after doing that for awhile, you notice it makes you bored more so than you typically would be.<n><n>### Third instruction<n>Input: There were 500 people in a theater who wanted to get seats for an award winning movie. The movie theater offered tickets at $60 per person. When the people got to the movie theater, they found that ticket prices had gone up to $65 per person. The people all wanted to see the movie. They could have done any of the following:<n><n>Choose: a: refused to see the movie because they did not want to pay the extra $5; b: found five friends so they could share the cost of the ticket; c: spent $300 to get two group discount tickets; d: paid the extra $5 for the ticket; e: returned the ticket and got their money back.<n><n>### Response answer<n>### Input<n>You could have done any of these things: refusing to see the movie, getting 5 tickets, sharing the ticket cost with friends, return it and get your money back.<n><n>*If they had chosen option C there would still be no ticket space because:* they had planned to get one ticket and buy it themselves

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What's the nickname of the monster the beauty loved? Choices:  A: critical thinking B: congratulated C: equal opportunity D: compliments E: raffle tickets<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Select the correct response for the job. Then in a short paragraph, explain why you agree or disagree.<n><n>### Response 1:<n>I’d have to agree with A. I believe that we need to give the same opportunities to every student applying to the job. In the past, some employers would exclude certain groups of students who did not possess some type of higher education. They would then use this education as a way to discriminate or exclude those students from consideration. Now, the government prohibits discrimination of any sort in these hiring processes. By giving an equal opportunity to every person, the employers gives them a chance at succeeding without judging their merits or talents by their race or gender.<n><n>### Analysis:<n>In a short paragraph, explain whether you agreed or disagreed with the response. Support or explain with evidence from classwork, lecture, reading, and/or your own knowledge.<n><n>I agree that we should be fair with each and everyone who is applying for the job. The government wants to ensure that everyone is giving the same opportunities. In the 50’s, they had separate job opportunities for blacks and white. However, today, they believe that everyone should be treated equal no matter who they are.<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where is a good place to sore a wind instrument in you home? Choices:  A: under bed B: symphony C: music room D: band practice E: music store<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Instruction:Answer the multiple choice question below.<n><n>### Expected Input: There are 11 chairs for 10 people in a classroom. What is the total number of chairs for the class room?<n>Answer: 36 (one chair less than 13 people).<n><n>### Explanation:<n>A multiple choice question should have the expected input as well.<n>The question is to show a classroom has 11 chairs, but there should be 10 seats for ten people so there should be a chair less in the classroom.<n><n>### Requirements<n><n>```<n>	The class should have a method named find_multiple_choice_question.<n>	<n>	The method should be able to ask the user for an input that is a <n>	multiple choice question (in the form of a string).<n><n>	It should display the correct answer. The number of strings needed to <n>	be displayed should be variable.<n><n>	The code should be written with the following guidelines, but should<n>	also show good coding practices:<n>	-	Consistent naming.<n>	-	Followed a naming convention (camel case words/names should never<n>		be used in the code).<n>	-	No spaces in variable names.<n>	-	Declares each variable and gives it a data type.<n>	-	The indentation of the code should be aligned to the rules<n>		mentioned in the module guide, including curly bracket placement.<n>	-	Avoid “debug”, “trace”, “print”, and any code lines that could be <n>		called during the process of user interaction.<n>	-	Code should be modular (in other words, every code should fall <n>		into a unit of work; this unit of work should be in a method so <n>		each unit works independently).<n>	-	Define each variable at the top of the module and/or class.<n>	-	In a class method, a variable should only be accessed via “this”.<n>	-	The methods should be clearly defined (should describe the function<n>		of the methods).<n>	-	Use descriptive names for both argument names and final values.<n>	-

Choices:  A: early morning B: day time C: night D: afternoon E: daytime<n><n>### Response:		<n>A, B, or C.<n>```<n><n>### Output:Sarah was home the whole morning.<n>```<n><n>					A<n>				/	<n><n>### Output should look like:  Sarah was home the whole morning<n><n>			       	   B<n>			         |<n><n>### Output  should look like: Sarah was home the whole afternoon <n><n>			               C<n>			              |<n><n>### Output should look like: Sarah had been home the whole daytime   <n><n>### Instructions:Complete each step of the following series.<n><n>### Step 1:<n>6 = 5 + 1<n><n>### Output<n>```<n>6 = 5+1<n>$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$<n>5 = <n>$$$$$$$$$<n>$$$$$$$<n>4 =<n>$$$$$$$$<n>$$$$$$$ <n>3 =<n>$$$$$<n>$$$ <n>3+ 1 = <n>$$$$<n>$$$ <n>2 + 1 =<n>$$$<n>2 + 2 + 1 =  3<n>2 + 1 + 2 =  3<n>1 + 3 = <n>1 + -3 =  0<n>$$$$<n>$$$$$<n>1<n>$$$$$<n>0<n>```<n><n>## Instructions:Complete a series of steps of a pattern or formula.<n>```<n>A is multiplied by B and then added or subtracted by C.<n>A is multiplied again by the first B which was added or subtracted by the second C<n>The result is B multiplied by A, or if it was subtracted A is subtracted from B<n>A is multiplied or added to at least two times, or once subtracted from two<n><n>A is multiplied, 5, times<n>A is multiplied 4 more times<n>A is first added and then subtracted<n>A is multiplied and added again<n>```<n>Output:23<n>```<n>1 * 2 = 2<n><n>2 * 2 = 4<n><n>3 *2 =  6<n><n>6 * 5 = 30<n><n>35 * 1 =35<n><n>35 /1 = 35<n><n>36 + 2 = 38<n><n>38- 2

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:If you are driving too fast on an icy road you are being what? Choices:  A: deadly B: dangerous C: unconcerned D: stressful E: harder when weather bad<n><n>### Response:		I feel that driving too fast on an icey road is being unconcerned because if you are driving too fast then you are more likely to get in a car wreck.<n><n>### Input<n>You are driving too fast on a narrow road. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What has happened to a person's money after he or she has used the last of it? Choices:  A: dissipate B: flown C: disintegrate D: fall apart E: penultimate<n><n>### Response:		<n>The answer is E.<n><n>### Input2:Money has gone "down the tube" if someone has not taken care of it for a long time. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where can you find a place to eat and places to buy items of many different kinds? Choices:  A: city B: downtown C: own house D: bar E: shopping center<n><n>### Response:		City<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>You are given the task of evaluating other students' responses. Use your understanding of the language to evaluate them. Make any recommended suggestions or additions to the student(s) responses. If you find the response to be accurate and complete, please explain your response by either marking with an 'X' or just writing the word, "correct".<n><n>### Demystification:<n><n>These questions are tricky, but only because of the wording which may be confusing to some.<n><n>- The first question is asking you how many cards they have altogether. If you take both Mara and Brenda the total number of cards they have combined is 15!<n><n>- The second question is asking you how far Pete traveled after leaving his house and before coming home. The first 5 blocks plus the remaining 20 block trip is 25 blocks in all.<n><n>- The third question is asking you how much coffee from each thermos. Genevieve droned 3 of the thermoses together which were a full of 3 pints of coffee.<n><n>- The fourth question is asking you how does Alannah, beatrice, and queen compare? Alannah has 30 more than Beatrix and Queen has 5 books more than Alannah. Now, it is asking you how many books will Beatrix have altogether? The answer is 140.<n><n>- The final question is asking you where can you find a place where you can eat and buy items of many different types of places. The answer would be "E", shopping center.<n><n>### Feedback:<n>You need to explain WHY you gave the answer that you gave to the individual(s). If you think there is room for improvement, write suggestions to the individual(s), like "be more specific".<n><n>- The first response asked you to say "D".<n><n>- The second response asked you to say city.<n><n>- The Third response asked you to say: "These questions are tricky because...."<n><n>The Fourth response asked you to say E.<n><n>In the final response the instructor asked for a specific place as you can see.<n><n><n>

How many people like both fruit and vegetables?<n><n>### Response<n><n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>Below is an instruction that describes task. Write a response to answer and complete the request.<n><n><n>### Instuction: <n><n>An automobile manufacturer sold 50,000 model cars at $21,000 each. They also sold 30,000 pickup trucks at $26,000 each and 40,000 small SUV's at $28,000 each on credit. They collected their total receipts from the trucks and SUV's and then paid cash for the cars. After all payments were made. they had $40,00 more cash to pay debts. How much of the gross receipts were cash sales?<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>CARS = \($50,00 * \$21000\)$ = \($105,000,000\$)\n<n>TRUCKS = \($30 * \$26000\$ = \($78,000, \$40000\$TOTAL \$1120000\$) \n<n>SUV\$40 * \$28000\$= \$1120,00, \$400,00 TOTAL \$152000\$ \n<n>Gross receipts $1500000\n<n>Now cash sales was $400,0 00 -$\$15000

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. What sort of facility is he most likely visiting? Choices:  A: swimming pool B: actors and actresses C: fancy restaurant. D: gym E: theatre<n><n>### Response:		Bob is going to gym.<n><n>### Input:"I just don't have the time I used to! I work so many extra hours per week that I am always busy."Which of the following activities are most likely being mentioned?Choices: A: sleeping B: dining C: driving to and from work D: eating at a fast food restaurant<n><n>### Response:"I just don' think I understand!" Which statement most likely follows when asked a difficult question?Choices: A. "Is the other answer more correct?"<n><n>### Input :Which is more expensive? 10 bananas, or 2 apples, or 1 orange?<n><n>### Response :2 apples are more expensive than 10 bananas because an apple costs more than a banana.<n><n>Because 1 apple is worth more than 1 banana, 2 apples are more valuable than 10 banana.<n>Therefore 2 apples = 10,000(10) bananas.<n><n>But 1 apple = 600(6) bananas.<n>Thus 10,050 bananas are more expensive than 2 apples.<n><n><n>### Input - (from the input above, this is a different question, same  input)<n><n>For the previous question, find the relative values of the units,  the cost of 10 bananas or 1 apple and the cost of 2 apples<n><n>Input :2 apples = 2 * 600 = 1,200<n><n>10 bananas = 10 * 100 = 1 * 1,000 = 10,500<n><n>The cost of 2 appes = 2 * 1,20 = 2,400<n><n>The relative value of 1 apple is 1 * 10,5 = 105<n><n>The relative value 2 apples is 10 * 2 = 20<n><n>The relative values of apple and banana are 105:20. This says you need 20 bananas to equal one apple.<n><n>Apples cost twice as much per apple as bananas, which we can call the relative cost.<n><n>Relative cost of apple = relative cost of banana

He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where would you put a computer other than a desk? Choices:  A: apartment B: table C: school D: office E: house<n><n>### Response:		<n>### Input:<n><n>```c<n>#include <stdio.h><n><n>int main(){<n>    int numb1, numb2, ans;<n>    printf("Enter number 1: ");<n>    scanf("%d", &numb1);<n>    printf("Enter Number 2: ");<n>    scan("&%d",&numb2);<n>    if (numb1 > numb2 ){<n>        ans= numb1 - numb2;<n>    } else if (numb1 < numb2){<n>        ans = numb2 - numb1;<n>    } else{<n>        printf("Error");<n>        return 0;<n>    }<n>    printf("The result of : %d", ans);<n><n>return 0;<n><n>}<n>```<n><n>

Input:All of the cards in a pack of playing cards are of the same species. A king is 21, a jack is 11, and a queen is 12. If 6 kings and 5 queens and 4 jacks equals 100, how many cards are in the whole pack?<n><n>**Response** : 46<n><n>**Comments :** <n>There are a total of 52 cards in a pack. So,<n>Since there are x amount of kings, queens, and jacks there must also be x amount of cards left.<n>x = a + c<n>100 - (x) = b<n>b = 100 -11 x + 11 x =100 - (52 -5 - 4)* x + ( 52 .5 - 4  *  11 x )<n>( 52.5 - x * 4 ) = 12 x <n>0.5 - ( 12 - x ) = 100<n>12 x + 100 = ( 52.5 + x ( 12 - 100/12x)).075<n>52 x + 120 = 411.075*x<n>472.2 - 411 + 52 = 10.2<n>10.2 = 100*0.075 = 75*0.1<n>75.1.075<n>.9875.

Choices:  A: company B: airport C: wall D: computer network E: love<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>You have to be thinking about it all throughout the day and figuring out what is good, what you like, and what you don't. But, I got a lot of experience and help from my parents.<n><n>### Analysis<n><n><n>When people are in the military or police force, they need to exercise and eat healthy to protect against trauma and the elements of the natural world. They also must eat nutritious foods to keep them fighting fit for as long as possible. The two groups of men and women often find their food in small quantities because they travel with them for long periods of time. The police and military often serve hot dogs because they can easily heat them in a microwave and provide plenty of nutrition. They may also serve canned tuna because it is less acidic than salmon and provides a lot of protein. The two groups of people often choose canned vegetables.<n><n><n>Canned foods are convenient because people do not need to spend time in the kitchen, and there are few ingredients to prepare meals. Therefore, they are often easier to prepare, and the food will last for weeks or even years. They are also inexpensive because they are easy to store. However, they can be expensive if someone buys more of them. Finally, the canned foods themselves are usually less nutritious than the foods that people make from scratch.<n><n>### Explanation<n><n>### Source Code:<n>https://github.com/nobody-in-particular/A-Guide-for-Data-Analysts/tree/master/Assignments/Multiple-Choice-Task<n><n>### Notes:<n>This is an explanation of something. Here is the source code for the multiple choice task.<n><n>### Example solution:<n>```<n>If someone else makes a good point, I'll give them my respect and say they are right about that point.<n>```<n>### Comments:<n>There should be some comments before the first example.<n><n>### Changes:<n>- The program takes some time to load in an external library to load and process the JSON.<n>- A lot of the input data is redundant:<n>  - It isn't necessary to load both the person and the name of the food in their name.<n>  - The program could use the same person data to process the other food name.<n>

Show the array with that multiplication.<n><n>### Function<n>function multiply(array) <n>{<n>   var secondArray = ["a", "n", "d", "r"];<n>   for (i = 0; i < secondArray.length; i++)<n>   {<n>      firstArray[i] = firstArray[i] + array[i];<n>   }<n><n>}<n><n>output<n>[0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5]<n><n>### Instructons - <n>Create an array of strings that takes user input until the user types "quit".<n><n>### function:<n>function get_data(){<n>   console.log("Please give me a string:");<n>   var input = prompt("Enter the string:");<n>   if(input == 'quit'){<n>     return 0;<n>   }<n>   else{<n>      return 1;<n>   }<n>}<n><n>Input : "Please give me a string:"<n><n>### Response :<n>Please give me a string

If you are off by 20 points or more, go back to the beginning and try again. If you have not reached the point that you got a 'Try Again' message, then you should keep trying until you do. No punishment for 'Try Again's. The first 2 'Try Again's should be considered 'practice tries'. <n><n>### Instructions:<n>Input: A number line with 20 tenths place holders. The tenths place holder is labeled 0, and the numbers go down to 10. After each number is added to the line, it shifts right by one position, moving the 1 to the right. A number is read off the line, and we wish to add one to its original position.<n><n>Example: The number is 89. The number 90 is placed in the 10 position. The line shifts right to form 91, and the 9 is now in the 10 holder. Therefore 91 is added to the original number 89, and the result is _____.<n><n>### Incorrect submission:<n><n>Input: A number is added to its original position<n><n>Expected: 91<n>Actual: 9<n><n>### Correct Submission:<n>```java<n>import java.util.Scanner;<n><n>public class Answer {<n>	public static void main(String[] args) {		<n>```<n><n>### Answer 2<n>```java<n>import javax.swing.JOptionPane;<n><n>public class Calculator {<n>	<n>    public static void main(String args[]) {<n>        Scanner scanner = new Scanner(System.in);<n>        <n>

You want to know the total cost of driving around the carnival. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Choices:  A: hang in closet B: sniff C: get dirty D: become soiled E: air out<n><n>### Response:		<n>***If clothes have developed a stench and can't be laundered, you must get dirty if you want to use them.***<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>***The smelly clothes should be air-dried.***<n><n>## Solution:<n><n>Below are a few different solution.<n><n>## Solution 1:<n><n>```javascript<n>var answer = false;<n><n>if(Janet > Brenda && Mara >= Janet){<n>    var sum = Janet + Mara;<n><n>    if (Sum > 150) {<n>        var difference = Sum - 150;<n><n>        if(difference >= 20 && difference >= 9) {<n>            answer = 211-150;;<n>            return answer;<n>        }else{<n>            return false;<n>        }<n>    }<n>}<n>else{<n>    return false;<n>}<n><n>```<n>

It shows that multiple lines are owned by different people.<n><n>### Input<n>The ratio of the amount of time it takes to clean Janice's room before it is considered clean vs. the amount of time it took to clean the room after it was considered clean is 2:1. If the room took Janice 25 minutes to clean, then how long did it take after she deemed it clean?<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>Janice took 25 minutes to deem a room clean. That means the ratio was 50:1, so she cleaned the room for 50 minutes to get it in pristine condition.<n><n>### Response<n>>**D:** Cleaning the room took 25 minutes. Once it was deemed clean, the room took 50 additional minutes to be clean enough for a king's chambermaid. (See [Clean My Room](https://www.reddit.com/r/dadjokes/comments/u738fv/clean_my_room_for_a_king/))<n><n>### Input The time at which a particular activity takes place relative to another activity is the order of their occurrence.<n>### Demonsteration<n><n>The order of the occurrence is not relevant. It is only whether the activity occurred in relation to another activity.<n><n>### Respose<n>>**C:** Janice's room is a mess. She has just cleaned the room and deemed it not messy. There is still a lot of work to do.<n><n>###Input When ordering pizza for a conference, a man chooses a large pie with 5 toppings and asks how much he owes. The clerk says that 5 topped cheese pies are currently $10 each, but he will deduct a $45 fee for the total number of toppings on a large cheese pizza in order to determine the cost.<n>> How much did the pizza cost?<n><n>###Demostration<n><n>A large cheese pizza is $10 plus $45, making the total $55.<n><n>###Respose<n>>**E:** The full $55. (A doughnut would be nice

Choices: A: 144 B: 512 C: 10 D: 3<n>### Response: 512<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question:<n><n>How many blocks did Pete walk in order to go to the post office?<n><n>### Demostration<n>- Pete walked 5+20 = 25<n>- 25 = 150<n>- Pete's total: 150 - 40 - 150 = 0<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Instructon:Answer this question as accurately as possible.<n><n>-2<n>-2<n>- 12<n><n>## Demo Instructions:<n>-2<n>- -2 --> 2<n>- -2 / 1 = -2/1 = -2 --> -2<n>- -12 / 1 = 12 / 1 - 2 -- 12 -2 is the same as 10

Choices:  A: get arrested B: problems C: sober D: intoxication E: pleasure<n><n>### Response:		I think that the person is definitely buying to be arrested, because you drink so much, you eventually can't walk in a straight line, you have to pee a lot (usually in the middle of the street), and that is bad luck because people start calling you "drunk driving" because you're not supposed to drive if you're drunk. I think the biggest reason for buying alcohol for drinking is because it leads to funny jokes and people laught at you. I personally think that you should drink less alcohol because in the long run you die earlier and more likely. Alcohol gets into your bloodstream and eventually leads to death so if you drink even once in awhile, you're going to die at an earlier age. You might say that only buying alcohol to not be arrested is a bad idea. Yes, it is a bad idea if you don't drink, only because when you buy alcohol, you most likely will not get arrested at all. If you choose to just drink, you will eventually have a reason to get arrested, and if you get arrested, you'll go to a court and get a lawyer. If you don't get a lawyer, you'll probably get arrested, and if they did catch you drinking and driving, you'd just go to trial and the judge will give you a fine between 500 and 1000 dollars and you'll have a huge record on you for the rest of your life. I don't really mind it if you drink, so long as you don't do anything stupid like steal, molest children, or kill someone.<n><n>### Input<n><n>How do you know if a group is a clique?<n><n>### Response<n><n>A clique is considered a group if everyone hangs out together in one group. Your function should have the following code signature: `print_distinct_numbers_from (a, b)`.  Your function should return nothing.<n><n>Write a function called `print_distinct(a)` that takes in an array of numbers, and displays the distinct numbers found in that array.<n><n>To achieve this, you will have to create 4 functions: `distinct_number`, `not_distinct_number`, and then `print_distinct` to do so.<n><n>Your `distinct_number` function simply returns `true` for a number that is distinct in the array, and `false` for a number that does not have a unique occurrence.<n><n>Your `not_distinct` function simply checks if a number is the first occurance or not.<n><n>Your `print_distinct`, for the challenge, should return a `string`, and have the following format:<n><n>| Distinct Number | Not Distinct Number |<n>:--- | :--- |<n><n>A)1 | B)2 | C)3 | D)4 | E)5 |<n><n>A)6<n><n>For example:<n><n>Input: [1, 2, 3, 3, 4]<n>Output: Distinct: 1, 3<n>Not Distinct: 2, 4<n><n>Input: [5, 4, 3, 5, 5, 3, 2, 4, 5, 6, 6, 5, 8, 7, 1, 5, 4,. 9, 4, 8,. 7. 5, 4]<n><n>Output (distinct_numbers): Distinct: 1<n>Not Distinct: (3 is not unique, 7 is not unique, 4 is not unique, 5 is not unique, 8 is not unique, 9 is not unique, and. 7. is not unique)<n><n><n>```php<n>namespace Example;<n><n>public function printDistinct($array) {<n>    // printDistinct -> calls distinct, prints_distinct<n>    $distinct_numbers = $this->distinct($array);

He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What is the hope of playing sports without competition? Choices:  A: running B: have fun C: balls touch D: winning E: get tired<n><n>### Response:		<n>- A: I should run and having fun.<n>- B: I should have fun and running.<n>- C: playing with balls to touch is not playing on my own.<n>- D: It will end with having fun and competion.<n>- E: I won’t exercise because I will get tired.<n><n>### Input:- What is your birthday?<n><n>- What is Pete and Jack's birthday?<n>- How old are you?<n>- It’s my birthday.<n>- Jack is older than Pete<n>- Jack has a birthday and my birthday<n>- My birthday is in 2020.<n>- Who is older?<n>- Jack!<n>- The boy is 20 years old.<n>- Pete’s birthday is in 1995<n><n>Input: Who is older?<n><n>### Response<n>You can put the names Pete and Jack, or Pete and I.<n><n>### Output: Pete is older<n><n>You can put the name of the person instead of I<n>

If the blank is given a noun, you can create an adjective or noun. If it is given an adjective, you can create a noun or adverb. If it is given a preposition and a noun, you do not change it. Remember to include the word _than_ if it is called for in the prompt.<n><n>### Example: The blank in: There is a more expensive model of the calculator that __$___, a new model will be available in a few months.<n>will be: $649<n><n>### Instruption:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Input:<n>Write 10 words about the life of William Shakespeare.<n><n>## Output:<n>(Sorry, too long for word count)<n><n>### Input and Output:<n>Write 15 words about each of the following terms given below:<n><n>### Answer:<n>- Antecedent: Dad is going to the supermarket, and so I cannot help him.<n>- Conjunction: But<n>- Connective: Although<n>- Infinitive: To go<n><n>### Input-Output:<n>- Choose the word or phrase to fill in the blank in the following sentence.<n><n>### Answer to Sentence:<n>I have just finished studying for my exam, and the time I have spent studying is ___ and ___.<n><n>### Answer for Sentence:<n>15 minutes and 30 minutes<n><n>### Answer Sentence:<n>When my parents get home, I ___ a cup of Milo before dinner.<n><n>### Input to Write 20 Sentences:<n>Write 20 sentences that are in the past and explain why the action happened:<n><n>### Sentences to Write:<n>- I went to the zoo, but there wasn't any animals there.<n>- When I got to the zoo there was no animals in it.<n>- There weren't any animals in the zoo when I went.<n>- The zoo was empty when we got there.<n><n>### Complete the Sentence:<n>I did not have anything to wear, and so I was not going to the

Book shop is the best place to watch four leggeds in a race.<n><n>### Input 2:Where would you sit to watch four-leg animals complete? Choices A: bookstore B C:house D:friend E:building<n><n>#### Choice 1:<n><n>I would sit on race track to watch four legg animals complete. Race track is the best to watch four leggers in a race. It is very easy to travel race track when there is a lot of crowd around you. In most of race tracks, it is not necessary that the person comes in race on his or her own vehicle. He can simply hire a cab or car and join race. <n><n>#### Choices 2:<n><n>For watching races, I would like to sit in the house. Watching four legged creatures running in big race is more fun if we sit in nice house. I would like to have a lot of space in building for viewing races.<n><n>###Input 3:If Janet has 3 times as many books as Carla, what is the difference between their numbers of books?<n><n>#### Choices are: <n><n>Janet has 1.7 books more.  <n><n>Carla has 35 books.  <n><n>Janet has a total 12 books. Janet Books: 1 - 6  <n>Carla Books: 7 - 35  <n><n>Carla Books:35  <n><n># 2.Write some code in the method called findTriangle() that will return the area of the triangle given that: Input:The area of a triangle is 3.9 square units. The perimeter (= sum of the lengths of the sides) of the triangle in 15 units. Given that the height of the triangle (the dimension of the triangle's base) is 4 units, what is the height of the triangle?<n>---<n>If the triangle is given for instance <n>Square of its base =3.9<n>Perimeter of triangle in 15<n><n>Then the height of the triangle = 4<n><n>### Input<n><n>The perimeter of a triangle is 15 units. The area of the triangle is 3.5 square units. Given that the base

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What could a balalaika be needed for? Choices:  A: artist junkyard B: music store C: singing D: symphony E: orchestra<n><n>### Response:		<n>### Instructional Notes:<n>It is possible to use a nested IF structure. This is the preferred method as the two choices that will be selected will be at the end of their nesting.<n><n>This is a multiple choice, so the response would be a `select` statement. As it is a nested selection with two end results, you can nest the selections to get the results you wish to get.<n><n>### Example:<n>```<n># This would be the select in the response<n># selection #1 with the first choice selected<n>$balalaika = "artist junkyard"<n># selection #2 with the second choice selected<n>$balalika = "music store"<n># selection #3 with the other selection out of the choices<n>$balalaika "singing"<n># The 4th choice would be for all the other options"<n>$balalaika="symphony orchestra"<n>```

Choices:  A: compliments B: understand themselves C: life partner D: second chances E: larger house<n><n>### Response:		<n>This is an excellent example of your work that shows your understanding of how to approach the problem.<n><n>#### 7.7<n>### Instruction<n>Use logical thinking to interpret an input–output format.<n><n>### Input<n>A local bank has decided to offer loans to applicants with good credit scores. A person’s credit score is increased by 2 points each time they pay off a credit card they already have. To qualify for a large loan of $10,000 or more, a borrower must have a credit score of at least 800. A local bank manager is concerned about a loan applicant because even though his credit score is currently 500. His score increases by at least 20 points each time he pays off a credit card and they have been on the same accounts for years now. What is the bank manager’s greatest concern?<n><n>#### 7-2<n>### InstructionWrite an instruction to complete the request.<n>When faced with a multi-part instruction, carefully read the entire instruction before beginning the task. This will maximize the use of your time and avoid wasting it guessing about how to approach the problem because you haven’t read all of the instructions carefully.<n><n>### Task<n>When faced with a large number of similar tasks, it’s often helpful to find a common factor that will reduce the task numbers. Using a common denominator can make all of the task numbers equal. If we divide a number by something, we get a new number divided by the number of the factor. In the example below, divide 1 and ½ by 10.<n><n>To divide by a divisor, multiply the whole number by a reciprocal divisor. The divisor is the inverse of the whole number. Thus, 10 is the inverse reciprocal of 1.<n><n>To divide 1 by 10, multiply 1 by 1/10. The product is 1 x 1/10 = 0.1 (because 10 x 0.1 = 1)<n><n>To divide ½ by 1, multiply ½ by 1/1<n><n>The product is ½ x 1/1 = 2<n><n>Because 2 = 10 x 1/2, 1 and ½ can be divided both by 10. In the example below

Choices:  A: pleasure B: accident C: get somewhere D: hurt E: falling down<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>- Option D can go. A get hurt because the wording on the answer can refer to an accident, a bruise or hurt.<n>- Option E need to removed.<n><n>### Input:{ 'Sara': 4, 'Frank': 2, 'Michael': 6, 'Kyle': 5, 'Katie': 1, 'Cole': 3, 'Alison': 10, 'Kevin': 7, 'Sophie': 6, 'Marcus': 11 }<n><n>- Response:<n><n>Option A & B are both correct.<n><n>Option C is correct is we can have more of them we just have to find the total of the other people.<n><n>Option D & E is not correct because we need to identify who has the most amount of people and who has the least amount of people.<n><n>Option F is also correct because we need to find out who has the least amount.<n><n>### Task: <n><n>This Task can be interpreted in different ways therefore the answer 20 cannot be used as correct because of that. <n>In this situation we have to think of this as who is there but we have to exclude the people who are currently away.   <n>We can say the response is correct because we can say there are more than 20 people. <n><n>Or this can be interperted in another way if there are less than 20 people and the response is not correct. <n><n>### The answer of 8 is also correct because we can also think of who is away as correct. <n><n>-<n><n>### Task :<n>We need to do a summation so we put  the option on 1 1/2.<n><n>### Response : <n>Response option A is correct because we have to take the sum of the numbers and get it to 1 1/4.<n><n>### The person who is not the correct answer is the one who answered option C because instead of a 1/2 they added 1/4 to the sum.

Choices:  A: sun himself B: thank god C: race against time D: express love E: to think about things.<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>>A,because he would like to feel the warmth coming from the sun<n><n>### Instructions: Write code that will solve the following problem.<n>Write a program to create 2 types of pads with the same dimensions 3 inches by 2 inches. One type of pad will be white and contain words. The other type will be red and contain images. The white words pad will allow users to change the font size between 5 points and 40 points. The red images pad will have a limit of no more than 20 words.<n><n>### Output:<n><n><n>This is what it could be output<n>A white pad with words called `Words Pad` and a `Font size from 5 to 40 points, a red pad with images and less than 20 words called `Images Pad`.<n><n>### Output 2:<n><n>This is what I expected<n>There is only 1 white pad with words called Words Pad and a red image pad with less than 20 images called Images Pad.<n><n><n><n>### Output Explanation:<n>The first `IF` statement checks whether the font size is from 5 to 39 points in the white pad called `Words Pad`, if it is it would create a new pad called `WordsPad with a different colour called `Words Pad`.<n><n>The second `IF` statement checks if the font size is less than 5, if it is it would not create a pad and return an output of `Images Pad`. If it is between 5 and 40 it would return the `WordsPad Colour`.<n><n>The third `IF` statement checks the images in the `Images Pad`. it would return the image if it is less than 20 and give it the name `Images Pad otherwise it would return the Images Pad name of `Images Pad`.<n>

Choices:  feeling sad feeling lonely feeling angry feeling confused A:B: C: D: E:<n><n><n>### response:<n><n>Answsers:<n><n>A: feeling sad<n>B: feeling lonely<n>C: feeling angry<n>D:  feeling confused<n>A: feeling sad, feeling lonely<n><n><n><n>### Insturction:<n>In this problem, the numbers represented in math and the numbers from counting have been mixed up.<n><n>#### Example: 9-10-11-4-3-5<n><n>9-10-4-11-3-5<n>B:3<n>C:4-7-6-8<n>B-3 is right<n>C is 4-7-6 is wrong<n>D:5+4=9<n>B would not answer because there was no 3<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>(9-10-6-5)<n><n>5-7-3-8-2 (3-2 + 5-4-6-7 = 13-14-13)<n><n>13-14+13

Janet has twice as many cards than Brenda. How many cards do her, Janet, and Brad have in all if Brenda has 40 cards which are less than 15?<n><n>Answer: I think the question is wrong. Because if Brenda has 15 cards then what does the question mean? But you can write answer if you think the problem is wrong.<n>1. (Janet+9)-(Brad)  => (Brad) = (Janet-9)/2<n>2. ==> (Janet-9/2)*Brad = (Janet-18/2)*Brad<n>3. 9-(Janet-BRAD)/2=(Janet-BRAD/2)*40/2<n>4. ==> (Janet+BRAD)(9-40/2)=-40/2<n>5. ((Janet-40/2)+BRAD) =-40/2  -> 40-((Janet+BRAD)/2)<n>6. But it can not be 21  because it can not be divided 2<n>7. The correct answer is 210<n><n>### Output:<n>### Expected:211<n>### Submission:85<n>### Error:46<n>### Note:85/46 = 1.822588235294<n>### Note: <n>### Note:<n>

You can’t get there except by climbing up a steep staircase and crawling through windows.<!-------><n><n></details><details><summary>B. trash</summary><n>If the box is worthless, then it is the trash and the next step is to throw it outside.<n><n></details><!-- Details on how to answer the 5 questions above can be found below. --><n>

Then, add the numbers of the two items next to each other in each row. Finally, write the total at the end of each column.<n><n>| 1 | 2 | 3 |<n>---|---|---|---<n>| | | |<n>| A | B | C |<n>| | | |  *<n><n>| 1. | 2. | 3. |<n>---|--- |---|---<n>|  |  |  *<n><n>### Answer<n>The sum of items A-C column is 16.<n><n>### Task2 :<n>Give a number or letter to each of the items listed below. Then, find the total in each row and column.<n><n>| _______ | _______ | ____ | ________ | ________<n>--- | --- | --- | -- | ---<n>| 1.| 6.|12.| 10.|<n>| 4.| 2.|3.|<n>| 7.|<n>| 9.| 7.| 2.<n><n>### Answer:<n>The total of items A-C row is 28.<n>The total  of items A-B-C column is 48.<n>The total of items B-C-D column is 10.<n>The total of all columns is 24.<n><n><n>### Task3 :<n><n>Put an X through the box on the chart that corresponds to the answer to the problem below.<n>1. The script must be written from the third party perspective. It must contain at least 5 lines. Write the script 12 hours before 2019-11-12 03:59.<n><n>### Direction:<n>It's been a few days since the final exam. You have just received a grade on the final exam. The grade is higher than your class average. (It has been confirmed that the entire grade was distributed equally among people in the class.) Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where would I put a rosebush if I did not have any containers to store it in? Choices:  A: flower garden B: garden center C: pot D: pot E: formal garden<n><n>### Response:		My flower garden can accommodate a rosebush for storage.<n><n>### Input 2: Who would you buy a stuffed animal for if your 4-year old sister did not like that toy? I'd bring it with me as he doesn't play with stuffed animals, unlike your sister.<n>### Response 2: My sister, who is four-years old, isn't fond of stuffed animals. I'd purchase that toy for my grandmother, she'll love it.<n><n>### Output:<n>Below is an instruction that describes an output. The function must return a double precision number and must be defined as<n><n>```<n>  f(x,y) = x + y<n>```<n><n><n>Input: f(double a, double b)<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: function f(x, y)<n>    int f(int a, double b) = 6.5+b;<n><n>Output: 6.5+5;<n><n>### Input 3:<n>Describe a task for which you can use a function to accomplish it.<n><n>### Response 3:<n>Functions can easily solve the mathematical work and operations of any problem, and it is clear that it is a difficult task to apply it in the programming world. I can use a function that I define to find the factorial of a number by defining the function and adding the parameter. As described by the following statement, I need to understand this process:<n>```<n>fact(7)<n>```<n><n>Here the value of 7 is passed as the first parameter in the function and the code that represents 7 * 7 * 7. I can say that the factorial of 7 will be 7.<n><n>Now I can understand that the factorial of two numbers is just:<n>```<n>fact x y<n>```<n><n>where x and y are the variables that are passed as parameters to the function.<n><n>### Input  4:<n>There are two variables in a program, say X and Y. Both have the datatype double-precision floating number. If X is not 0.0, Y equals X+5. Otherwise, Y takes the maximum of X and 5. If X = 0 and Y = 0, Y is undefined. Write a line of code that sets Y to a value.<n><n>###Response 4:<n>If (X >0.0 ) then Y = X+5, Else Y = 5<n><n>###Input 5:<n>Input a function<n><n>```<n>function f(a,b) return [a+b, (a*b)/2)<n>```<n><n>Output [3 2]<n><n>###Input  6:<n>In a particular school, there are 15

Choices:  A: lungs and diaphram B: oxygen C: abdominal muscles D: air E: open throat<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Solution:<n>```python<n>if answer == 'a':<n>    print("Lungs and Diaphragm")<n><n>elif answer == 'e':<n>    print("Open Throat")<n><n>elif answer is in interval([1,3,5,7,9]):<n>    totalbooks = 0<n>    while totalbooks < total_number_of_books:<n>        books_in_stores = random.randrange(1,10)<n>        books = books_in_stories * 23<n>        total_number_of = books_in_story + 450<n>        total_number = total_number_of + 440<n>        total_num = total_number + random.choice([11,25,40,65,79])<n>        print(str(question) + "\t: " + str(total_num))<n>        total_num += random.choice([38,4, 11,131, 64])<n><n>        total_number += random.choice([77,80,70,55,25,96,14,10])<n>        try:<n>            total_number += 1<n>        except ZeroDivisionError:<n>            pass<n>        if total_number%1 == 0:<n>            total_num += 4<n>        else:<n>            total_nmb - 1<n>            total_num == 3<n>            print(total_book = 700)<n>```<n>

Choices:  A: space shuttle B: detroit C: stairs D: downtown E: elevator<n><n>### Response:		<n>Let J be the number of the floor John is currently on.John would go to the floor J+3 to reach the floor J+2.So J=floor J+3.If the detroit is 345 and the space shuttle is 500, he will use the detroit.The elevator goes from the detroit to the street, so he will use that last answer.<n><n>### Input :Jorge is a human who is a carpenter. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:One might find theirs open, with the letters that had been delivered stolen. Choices:  A: front door B: newspaper C: post office D: package E: mail box<n><n>### Response:		<n>**C**<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>```html+php<n><?php<n>        function solve($choice) {<n>        $choice_arr[] = $choice;<n>        $letter = mb_strlen($choice, 'UTF-8');<n>        $c = $letter % 3;<n>        if ($letter % 5!= 1) {<n>                    if (isset($choice_arr[$c])) {<n>                            echo 'C';<n>                            unset($choice_arr[$choice_arr[$c]]);<n>                            $choice_arr[$choice[$c]] = 'D';<n>                            return $letter - 5;<n>                    }<n>                    if (empty($choice_arr[$letter])) {<n>                            $letter -= 3;<n>                            $choice = shuffle($choice_arr);<n>                            return solve($choice);<n>                    }<n>                }<n>                if (empty($choice)) {<n>                        return 0;<n>                }<n>                return 2;<n>        }<n><n>        shuffle($choice_choice);<n>        $choices = 'C';<n>        $i = 0;<n>        $ans = 0;<n><n>        while ($choices!= $choice_choice) {<n>                $answer = solve($choice_choice); <n>                if (isset($choices[$answer])) {<n>                        $ans++;<n>                        $choices[$answer] = false;<n>                }<n>            $choices = $choose[$choice_choice];<n>            $i++;<n>        }<n>        if (isset($chooses[0])) {<n>        echo $answer + 1;<n>        } else {<n>        echo -1;<n>        }<n>                   <n>       ?><n>```<n><n>```html+python<n>solve = lambda x: len(x) % 5<n><n>ans = 0<n><n>for i in range(500):  <n>    ch = ['A','B','C','D','E'] # set of choices<n>    cnv = ch.index(solve(ch[i]))<n><n>    if cnv==0:<n>        ans += 1<n>    else:<n>        ch[cnv] = 'B'<n><n>print(ans)<n><n>```<n><n>```js<n>function isOpenableDoor

Choices:  A: rain forest B: research laboratory C: cage D: treetops E: south africa<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input2:<n>This time they took me away from home to a cage they like to call a lab. We go there for tests, where doctors wear white coats and poke me with needles and take tissue samples and all sorts of terrible things. I like to spend my weekends free from this place where cruel monkeys like me are poked and prodded by doctors.<n><n>### Problem Solving:<n><n>### Solution:<n>In the problem we get, When a monkey is taken from their home they are brought to a place where people wear white coat. So, the correct options will be B and E.<n><n><n>### Input1:<n>June 20th is a Sunday and it is the day the President gets sworn in that year.<n><n>### Solution1;<n>Here, 20th is the day of the month. We all know that dates are represented in the form dd/mm/yyyy. So we will take as inputs the day, month, and the year respectively. The problem is to find if the day on which the President gets sworn is Sunday or not.<n><n>### Input3:  <n>After that they were taken by the same men in white coats to the lab. I have no idea what the men do with us. Maybe its for science.<n><n>### Example4:<n>This time they take me to another place, where I'm sure it says "do NOT take" on the door, but people in white coats are taking me there anyway. They call it a lab, but there are no cages so the lab might actually be worse than the cage.<n><n>### Explanation1:<n>Here, we will be using the greedy algorithm to solve this problem by which we will take as input the string "don't take". After taking the first alphabet of the string as "d" we will take "n" as the second and "t" as the second and then for next iteration we will take the second letter of "n" as "a" and the next two letters of "k" as "t" and for the next iteration we take "t" from "t" of "ka" as our second letter and the next two letters as "e" from "e" from "ke". In this way, we can get the solution.<n><n>### Conclusion1
